Yeah, Spintires looks like a driving game, but its not. It is an open world physics simulation. And not just truck and mud simulation but everything, trees, rocks water. Its amazing. I was shocked when I saw a sapling get caught on the truck, bend over with truck and then as the truck past the sapling WHIPPED BACK. It also has a strategy element to it. There are a lot of different roads and trucks you could use and you have to find the best.

I stayed up until 4am playing the other night. I love this game!

Toribash is a physics based fighting game I've been playing on and off for quite a few years.

The best way to describe it is you can control your ragdoll character by putting its various joints in a few different states: Hold, Relax, Contract,extend, and the spine has rotate left/right)

You set up your joint movements and a ghost shows what your character will do with that set up. then time advances by 1/4 second, and you can alter the joints again.

Oh and its completely free. money only lets you customize your character, no gameplay benefits, everyone is equal.

To be honest, you could take the whole economy thing out of KSP and I would not shed a tear. Give me engines, tanks and physics and I am a happy camper.

I wouldn't call Spintires a physics game. It has physics implemented, but it's not essential element of the gameplay. Regarding some physic sandboxes I can recommend Phun / Algodoo and Universe Sandbox.

Another good physics (ish) game is Turbo Dismount. You have your sort of rag doll/crash test dummy thing and you smash it into stuff and through minefields and bowling pins and jump ramps and stuff. (Wow, I really love using the word "stuff".)It also is very Kerbal when your monster truck does a barrel roll, crashes through a tower, and hits a minefield . You could also try Beam.NG Drive, as it has some beautiful soft-body physics (though the game is still in alpha so that may be a bit screwy) and has planes and helicopters and stuff too
